text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC in Oxford Mississippi one of the
big uncertainties surrounding the
political community has now been
resolved John McCain says he will fly to
Oxford tonight to participate in the
first televised presidential debate with
Barack Obama but there remains no
clarity as to the outcome of either of
the two interrelated Gamble's John
McCain has taken one with the fate of
the bailout package the other with his
presidential campaign now John McCain
has faced political head winds all year
long given the public's desire for
change from the incumbent Republican
administration he achieved some momentum
coming out of his national convention
with the selection of Alaska governor
Sarah Palin as his running mate but that
Momentum's now been lost in the wake of
the financial crisis so a few days ago
John McCain took a major gamble said he
was suspending his campaign until he
could place himself at the center of the
attempts to resolve that crisis and it
was resolved part of that was his
attempt to delay this first presidential
debate the fact that he's reversed
course on that suggests that aids were
cognizant of the fact that the risks of
a backfire were increasing now that
relates to what was going on on Capitol
Hill yesterday Senate Democrats Senate
Republicans House Democrats were close
to the outlines of an agreement to
revise the Bush administration's bailout
package that they believe could pass the
Congress but House Republicans withheld
their support and so did John McCain
that left both of them vulnerable to the
charge that they were playing politics
with the national crisis what's happened
today is that negotiations have resumed
with House Republicans playing a more
active role President Bush came out at
the White House said there would be a
deal so did Senate Democrats and the
good news for john mccain is that the
markets have not collapsed that reduces
his potential exposure to political
blame still unclear as to what happens
if there is no deal by monday what the
markets do then now many republicans are
fearful that john mccain's gamble will
not pay off in the end but there remains
the chance that a deal will be struck
and it will be in a position to claim at
least part of the credit as one top
Republican strategist told me last night
if this pays off for john mccain i want
to take his campaign manager on a trip
to Las Vegas
